newsitem.title: HUNGARY: Budapest wheat futures rise, triggered by Chicago.
newsitem.headline: Budapest wheat futures rise, triggered by Chicago.

text.p: A limit-up rise of milling wheat futures on the Budapest Commodity Exchange (BCE) on Friday was mainly triggered by Chicago prices, traders said.
"A six to eight cents per bushel price rise was enough for Budapest prices to go higher as well," said Istvan Markus of Swap.
He added that domestic factors could not have caused the rise.
"On the basis of domestic news and crop forecasts prices should have gone down," Markus said.
Milling wheat futures rose by the daily allowed 400 forints per tonne limit for all maturities to finish at 24,830 forints for May, 22,300 for July and 23,970 for December.
The milling wheat price rise triggered an increase of 100 to 400 forints in feed wheat prices for the July to December maturities.
Old (1996) crop maize prices remained little changed in a fairly balanced market, Markus said.
"The market had calmed down, panic position-closings are over," he said.
May maize rose 100 forints to close at 18,400 forints, July eased 50 forints to 17,700 forints.

Markus said that the overheated Hungarian grains futures market is ripe for a correction and it should happen by the second half of next week, unless international prices go in the opposite direction.
"If the Chicago rise stops, a downward movement is likely to start here," he said.
Total grains turnover was 394 million forints or 957 contracts, with milling wheat accounting for 472 and maize for 360 contracts.
